event.desc: Between 514 and 518, Severuswrote a letter toPeter ofApamea, hoping to correct the bishop's views of ordinations that occur at the hands of those outside a particular diocese.

Severuswas aware of many letters written byPeterto himself and to the presbyterThomas, wherein Peteraccused Severusand others of breaking canon-law and tradition by allowing for ordinations outside of the diocese.

event.desc: Severusdefended his ordination practices by pointing out that many other godly bishops approved, includingJulian, who allowedSeverusto ordain the deaconIrenaeus, andDionysius, who allowedSeverusto ordain the deaconAnatolius.
Contrary to the opinion ofPeter, Severushad not ordainedLeontiusout of need, but in order to honour the man.
Severushad become acquainted withLeontiusthrough letters while living inPalestine.
In his letter, Peterreported toSeverusthatLeontiushad shaken the stability of the Church inApamea.
SeverusencouragedPeterto ordain the scholastics John son of MatronianandSergius.
Severusintended to ordain the scholastics PeterandMaximin.
